user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_timeout_millisec_:
```c
static int64_t
get_timeout_millisec_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       int32_t max_timeout)
{
  uint64_t d_timeout;
  mhd_assert (0 <= max_timeout || -1 == max_timeout);
  if (0 == max_timeout)
    return 0;

  if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if ((0 < max_timeout) && ((uint64_t) max_timeout < d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if (INT64_MAX <= d_timeout)
    return INT64_MAX;

  return (int64_t) d_timeout;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_timeout_millisec_:
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_get_timeout64 (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                   uint64_t *timeout64)
{
  uint64_t earliest_deadline;
  struct MHD_Connection *pos;
  struct MHD_Connection *earliest_tmot_conn; /**< the connection with earliest timeout */

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Illegal call to MHD_get_timeout.\n"));
#endif
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  if (daemon->data_already_pending
      || (NULL != daemon->cleanup_head)
      || daemon->resuming
      || daemon->have_new
      || daemon->shutdown)
  {
    /* Some data or connection statuses already waiting to be processed. */
    *timeout64 = 0;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (daemon) &&
      ((NULL != daemon->eready_head)
#if defined(UPGRADE_SUPPORT) && defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT)
       || (NULL != daemon->eready_urh_head)
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT && HTTPS_SUPPORT */
      ) )
  {
    /* Some connection(s) already have some data pending. */
    *timeout64 = 0;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */

  earliest_tmot_conn = NULL;
  earliest_deadline = 0; /* mute compiler warning */
  /* normal timeouts are sorted, so we only need to look at the 'tail' (oldest) */
  pos = daemon->normal_timeout_tail;
  if ( (NULL != pos) &&
       (0 != pos->connection_timeout_ms) )
  {
    earliest_tmot_conn = pos;
    earliest_deadline = pos->last_activity + pos->connection_timeout_ms;
  }

  for (pos = daemon->manual_timeout_tail; NULL != pos; pos = pos->prevX)
  {
    if (0 != pos->connection_timeout_ms)
    {
      if ( (NULL == earliest_tmot_conn) ||
           (earliest_deadline - pos->last_activity >
            pos->connection_timeout_ms) )
      {
        earliest_tmot_conn = pos;
        earliest_deadline = pos->last_activity + pos->connection_timeout_ms;
      }
    }
  }

  if (NULL != earliest_tmot_conn)
  {
    *timeout64 = connection_get_wait (earliest_tmot_conn);
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions in the provided code that are compile-time invariant and thus would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Specifically:

- In get_timeout_millisec_:
  - if (0 == max_timeout) — depends on parameter max_timeout (runtime).
  - if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &d_timeout)) — depends on the return value of a runtime function call.
  - if ((0 < max_timeout) && ((uint64_t) max_timeout < d_timeout)) — depends on runtime values max_timeout and d_timeout.
  - if (INT64_MAX <= d_timeout) — depends on runtime d_timeout.
  - The function contains no loops or conditionals with constant literals as their controlling expressions (no while(1) / if (1) / if (0), etc.).

- In the related MHD_get_timeout64 implementation and macros used by it:
  - Conditions (e.g. checks of daemon->fields, function-like macros such as MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_(daemon), and the for-loop control NULL != pos) depend on runtime state.
  - The mhd_assert macro is defined as ((void)0), so the assertion does not produce a controlling statement in the compiled code.

There are also no do-while loops with a constant false controlling expression (the allowed exception) nor any obvious intentional infinite-loop constructs that would be a permitted invariant. Therefore no fragments need investigation for Rule 14.3 based on the provided code.
